title: Quiz 7: Medicine FQE Sept 2013 Paper II
description: Medicine Paper II from September 2013. Covers General Medicine, Infectious Diseases, and Pharmacology in True/False and MCQ formats.

questions.question: Which of the following are MAJOR manifestations of Jones Criteria in the diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Major Jones Criteria: Carditis, Polyarthritis, Chorea, Erythema Marginatum, Subcutaneous Nodules. Fever is a Minor criterion.
questions.hint: Think 'JONES' (Joints, O-heart, Nodules, Erythema, Sydenham's chorea).

questions.question: Identify valid reasons for altering a patient's ARV drug regimen: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Regimens are changed for toxicity (major), interactions, failure, or pregnancy considerations. Minor toxicity is managed symptomatically.
questions.hint: Change needed when drugs don't work or are unsafe.

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman on TB treatment for 3 months tests HIV positive. What does she need? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Comprehensive workup is needed: Pregnancy test (for drug choice), CD4 (baseline immunity), Renal (for Tenofovir), and Prophylaxis (Cotrimoxazole).

questions.question: Which of the following are signs and symptoms of Infective Endocarditis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Classic signs include constitutional symptoms (weight loss, sweats) and embolic phenomena (Janeway lesions, petechiae). Cough is not a primary feature unless failure occurs.
questions.hint: FROM JANE (Fever, Roth spots, Osler nodes, Murmur, Janeway lesions, Anemia, Nail hemorrhage, Emboli).

questions.question: Select the known triggers for Bronchial Asthma:
questions.explanation: Asthma triggers include allergens, irritants (smoke), drugs (NSAIDs), stress, and comorbidities like GERD. Injections per se are not a trigger.
questions.hint: Things that irritate the airway or nerves.

questions.question: Which statements regarding Pulmonary Tuberculosis are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Major diagnostic test is tuberculin skin test
Chronic cough for more than two weeks is significant
Treatment for a new case takes 8 months
Treatment takes at least nine months

questions.explanation: Symptoms: Night sweats, chronic cough. Diagnosis: Sputum/GeneXpert (not Mantoux/Skin test for adults). Treatment: Standard is 6 months for new cases.

questions.question: Which of the following are classes of Antihypertensive drugs? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: All listed options are valid classes of antihypertensive medications.
questions.hint: A, B, C, D (ACEIs, Beta-blockers, CCBs, Diuretics).

questions.question: Which of the following opportunistic infections are associated with AIDS? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: All listed infections are common opportunistic infections in advanced HIV/AIDS.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common symptom of Peptic Ulcer Disease?
questions.explanation: Epigastric pain is the hallmark symptom. The others are less specific or complications.

questions.question: Which is the correct treatment regime for a new adult TB case?
questions.explanation: New cases: 2 months Intensive (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol) + 4 months Continuation (Rifampicin, Isoniazid).
questions.hint: 2 months of 4 drugs, 4 months of 2 drugs.

questions.question: What is required to diagnose Rheumatic Fever?

options.text: 2 major OR 1 major and 2 minor (plus antecedent infection)

questions.explanation: Diagnosis requires 2 Major criteria OR 1 Major + 2 Minor criteria + evidence of Strep infection.

questions.question: Which anti-tuberculosis drug is used for prophylaxis?
questions.explanation: Isoniazid Preventive Therapy (IPT) is the standard.

questions.question: Which of the following is CORRECTLY matched?

options.text: Tinea corporis – fungal infection of the trunk
Tinea capitis – fungal infection of toes
Tinea cruris – fungal infection of the scalp
Tinea pedis – fungal infection of the pharynx

questions.explanation: Corporis = Body/Trunk. Capitis = Scalp. Cruris = Groin. Pedis = Feet.

questions.question: Herpes Simplex Virus Type II has all the following features EXCEPT:

options.text: It is a sexually transmitted disease
It is caused by varicella zoster virus

questions.explanation: HSV-2 is NOT caused by Varicella Zoster Virus (which causes Chickenpox/Shingles).

questions.question: Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS) is:

options.text: Worsening of the clinical condition of the patient after starting ART
Appearance of new symptoms before starting ART
Major side effects caused by some ARV drugs
Is the same with viral load count

questions.explanation: IRIS is a paradoxical worsening of pre-existing infections as the immune system recovers on ART.
questions.hint: Immune system wakes up and fights hard.

questions.question: HIV makes the body weak and unable to fight opportunistic disease by:
questions.explanation: HIV targets CD4+ T-Lymphocytes (White Blood Cells).

questions.question: Peripheral neuropathy is a common complication of which drug?
questions.explanation: Stavudine (d4T) is notorious for peripheral neuropathy. Isoniazid also causes it (treated with Pyridoxine), but Stavudine is the classic ARV cause here.
questions.hint: An older ARV known as d4T.

questions.question: Which of the following is a Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)?
questions.explanation: Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidney (Upper UTI). The others are reproductive tract or genital skin infections.

questions.question: The following are bacterial infections EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Giardiasis is caused by a protozoan (parasite), not a bacteria.
questions.hint: It's a parasite, not a bacteria.

questions.question: A long term complication of Diabetes Mellitus is:
questions.explanation: Cataracts/Retinopathy are chronic long-term complications. The others are acute metabolic complications.
